stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the Raphael the Raven boss fight, which takes place on a small moon with planetary gravity. He debugs the boss's hitbox, balances the difficulty, programs the cutscene transitioning Mario to the moon, and solves the design problem of how the player gets the star after the fight, ultimately opting for the simplest solution.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is carefully tuning the boss difficulty by adjusting its movement speed after attacks, trying to find a balance between too easy and too hard.
development_findings.quote: It's very hard to find the correct velocity there, because if you set it to 0, the fight is laughably easy, and if you set it like what I have right now, it's a little too hard.

development_findings.summary: Despite using planetary gravity, a mechanic famous in Super Mario Galaxy, Kaze wants to ensure the boss fight's identity remains firmly rooted in Yoshi's Island.
development_findings.quote: I don't want people thinking of Mario Galaxy with this. This is Yoshi's Island.

development_findings.summary: The game's hub world is inspired by the 'Yoshi's Tropical Island' board from Mario Party, where players will use coins to fund projects like building bridges to enable progression.
development_findings.quote: The hub world is gonna be Yoshi's Island, of course. You know the Maori Party Board? Yoshi's Tropical Island, where there's fruits everywhere? I want it like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally designed a potential sequence break, allowing players who cleverly get to the boss's egg before the fight to earn the star and skip the encounter entirely.
development_findings.quote: If someone figures out a way to ground pound the egg without triggering the bossfight before then they deserve to just get the star like that and skip the bossfight.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided against using a pipe for the player to return from the moon boss fight due to both the technical difficulty of the required math and his feeling that it was not a visually compelling solution.
development_findings.quote: I think the pipe sucks. It sucks programming wise. And it's also not really very visually clear.

development_findings.summary: A major bug where the boss was invincible was caused by code that scaled the boss's model down to zero, which in turn made its hitbox disappear.
development_findings.quote: The scale of Raphael Raven was too small. He was scaling down so far that his hitbox was 0.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates that the project is currently 'just over 80 percent' complete.
The planetary gravity effect is achieved using quaternions and matrix transformations, a technique Kaze believes is accessible to others with some research.
development_findings.quote: You just need some quaternions and then you can actually just google everything... if you watch my newest video and you know a little bit about quaternions you can do this too.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experiencing stress from dealing with bureaucracy, which is causing him mental pain outside of the project.
context_findings.quote: I'm in mental pain because of bureaucracy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels frustrated and unfairly cast as the villain when he pushes back against community pressure for a release date.
context_findings.quote: When people harass me about the release date and I tell them that I want the whole family to... I am the bad guy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes in a personal philosophy that physical health is directly linked to mental well-being.
context_findings.quote: You gotta take care of your body. If you wanna take care of your mind. That's my thought process.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is planning to increase his YouTube video output, with help from a new editor, as a way to increase his income for his family.
context_findings.quote: I'm thinking I will just pump out a lot of videos... I'm gonna make more money for my family.

context_findings.summary: Kaze notes the contradictory nature of community feedback regarding game difficulty, finding it impossible to please everyone.
context_findings.quote: The comments I get on my YouTube is either like, oh wow, this level looks way too easy, or oh wow, this level looks way too hard. No one ever says Kaze, the difficulty of this looks perfect to me.

biobak.summary: Kaze is excited for Biobak to create a dynamic, rotating background for the Raphael the Raven boss fight to enhance its visual spectacle.
biobak.quote: Dude, Biobak, you can make this fight look so fucking cool with the background. Imagine the whole background here just rotating around.

biobak.summary: Kaze specifically implemented code to trigger the boss's color change after an attack to accommodate a visual effect designed by Biobak.
biobak.quote: I made him get his color only after he does the stomp so that the effect that you want in Biobak can be made.

biobak.summary: There was a creative conflict between Kaze's implemented cutscene and Biobak's concept, which involved the boss blocking the moon. Kaze is trying to find a solution.
biobak.quote: But wait. That's completely incompatible with the other idea. You had Biomex. How is he going to obstruct the moon if we do this?

zeina.summary: Zeina created the original animations for the meteor projectiles in the boss fight, which Kaze then tweaked for his specific implementation.
zeina.quote: I think Zeina made it. I just made some small changes to make sure it works better here.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for creating all the necessary animations for the Raphael the Raven boss, which are pending implementation.
zeina.quote: Yeah, Zeina is currently working on all the animations we need... vfx sfx and camera shakes and stuff like that.

zeina.summary: Kaze notes that Zeina (referred to as Reina) dislikes the 'Crazy Bus' video game theme music, which was played due to a donation.
zeina.quote: Congratulations we now know reina hates crazy bus

key_stories.title: Balancing the Boss Fight Difficulty
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to balance the boss fight's difficulty. After his initial attempts were either too easy or too hard, he implemented a dynamic system where the boss becomes progressively easier over time, reflecting a design philosophy that values accessibility over pure punishment.
key_stories.challenge: The boss fight against Raphael the Raven was either too easy or too difficult. Kaze himself struggled to beat the harder version on stream.
key_stories.process: Kaze first made the boss stop after attacks, which was too easy. He then made it only slow down, which was too hard. He rejected scaling difficulty to player health and instead decided to make the boss's slowdown effect increase with each attack cycle.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a dynamic difficulty system where the boss slows down more over time. This ensures the fight remains challenging initially but becomes easier for players who are struggling, guaranteeing eventual success.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we do the pattern to increase trick, and what we do is we make it slower the longer the fight goes. That way, everyone is guaranteed to beat eventually, sounds good.

key_stories.title: Solving the Return from the Moon
key_stories.summary: Kaze faced a design and technical challenge in returning the player from the moon-based boss arena. After finding the programming for a pipe too complex and other ideas thematically inappropriate, he pivoted to a simpler solution: having the star appear on the moon, removing the need for a return trip entirely.
key_stories.challenge: After defeating the boss on a separate moon, there was no clear or easy way for Mario to return to the main level.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to program a pipe for Mario to enter. He found the math required to orient it on the spherical planet (quaternion to Euler conversion) to be frustrating and 'stupid.' He dismissed other ideas like 'Yoshi magic' or a wing cap before settling on simplifying the problem itself.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze abandoned the idea of a return trip. He decided to have the Power Star spawn directly on the moon after the boss is defeated, making it the simplest and most elegant solution.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the pipe sucks. It sucks programming wise. And it's also not really very visually clear. Why that would happen.

key_stories.title: Merging Cutscene Concepts
key_stories.summary: A creative conflict arose between Kaze's implemented cutscene and Biobak's artistic concept for the same sequence. The stream captures Kaze's real-time process of identifying this conflict and beginning the collaborative work of merging two different creative visions.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze and Biobak had different, potentially conflicting, ideas for the cinematic that transitions Mario to the moon for the boss fight.
key_stories.process: Kaze implemented a cutscene where Mario flies to the moon. He then reviewed Biobak's idea, realized it conflicted with his current version, and began openly brainstorming how the two concepts could be reconciled.
key_stories.outcome: The situation is unresolved in the stream. Kaze acknowledges the incompatibility and seems to be trying to find a way to merge his implementation (Mario flying on a parabola) with Biobak's concept (the raven blocking the moon).
key_stories.key_quote: But wait. That's completely incompatible with the other idea. You had Biomex. How is he going to obstruct the moon if we do this?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that his implementation of the intro cutscene is 'completely incompatible' with an idea from Biobak that involved the raven blocking the moon. He seems to be trying to merge the ideas but the specifics are unclear.

open_questions.context: Kaze states that Zeina is creating all the animations for the Raphael the Raven boss. He receives the files at the end of the stream but doesn't have time to implement them.
